awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of Mees Massively-multipleXed Coronal Spectropolarimetric Magnetometer (mxCSM) for Ground and Space Coronal Magnetometry
awd_abstract_narration:
This 4-year MRI project is to develop high resolution instrumentation at the Mees Solar Observatory in Hawaii, an EPSCoR state, which will measure the magnetic field of the solar corona. The corona, the atmosphere of the sun, is where space weather events originate. Solar eruptions (coronal mass ejections and solar flares), which occur in the corona, are complex electromagnetic events and can have significant impact at Earth and throughout the solar system. In the near-Earth environment, they can adversely impact satellite electronics, cause disruptions to power grids, and harm humans in space. The effects of a 1 in 100 year storm are now the focus of the NSTC subcommittee on Space Weather Research, Operations, and Mitigation. Currently, measurements are of the solar corona modest sensitivity and resolution and from a single vantage point, that of Earth. These single point measurements are complicated to interpret due to the highly 3D nature of the system. This project will both serve as a test for a new paradigm of future high resolution space-borne instruments enabling multi-point measurements and generate unprecedented data that will enable entirely new science. This instrument is designed to work as a system with NSF's Daniel K. Inouye Solar Telescope which will take very high resolution images from a smaller field of view in the low corona. 

The massively-multiplexed Coronal Spectropolarimetric Magnetometer or mxCSM, is a 15-cm hybrid off-axis mirror coronagraph equipped with a six-channel spectropolarimeter to measure the magnetic polarization signals of six coronal emission lines (CELs) simultaneously over a large field of view (FOV). With its high polarization sensitivity and large FOV, mxCSM will be able to observe the evolution of the linear polarization of the whole field with a high temporal resolution sufficient for the study of coronal mass ejections (CMEs) and other solar eruptions. It will also measure the line-of-sight component of coronal magnetic fields in active regions with lower spatial and temporal resolution. Synoptic data from mxCSM can be used to perform tomographic inversion of the magnetic fields of large, long lived coronal structures. These new coronal polarization data will yield stringent observational constraints for coronal model validations, and will help advance our understanding of the processes that heat and structure the corona.

por.por_cntn:
This project has resulted in the development of new integral field and high-efficiency multiplexed spectroscopy technologies with far-reaching impact beyond solar physics and astronomy. 

The objective of this project is the further development of enabling technologies for future solar instrumentation using massive-multiplexing strategies to provide order-of-magnitude performance improvement in their sensitivity, field of view coverage, and operational efficiency. The massively multiplexed Coronal Spectropolarimetric Magnetometer (mxCSM) adapted a multi-slit spectrograph design optimized for coronal magnetic field measurement with very large field of view (FOV) coverage. The multi-slit design of mxCSM was enabled by the high-efficiency ultra-narrow dense wavelength division and multiplexing (DWDM) bandpass isolation filter developed for fiber-optic telecommunication. The DWDM technology for telecom was limited to the short-wave IR wavelength bands (1.3 and 1.6 um) with small size (~ 10 m). This MRI project expanded the DWDM technologies into visible wavelengths and with large-aperture (70 mm) and will benefit future astronomical instrumentation. mxCSM was successfully constructed and installed at MSO, and will provide new large-field (1 deg) coronal magnetic field observations that complements the limited-field (0.08 deg) observations from the Daniel K. Inouye Solar Telescope (DKIST), and enables observations of coronal mass ejections (CMEs) as they propagate from the low corona into the heliosphere.

A second technology developed by this MRI project is the machined Image slicer based Integral field unit (IFUs). This development effort took advantage of the ultra-precision free form micro optics fabrication capability of Canon Inc. to enable the design and construction of large format image slicers for integral field spectroscopy.  Canon’s ability to fabricate image slicers with slicer mirror width in the 10s of micrometers, 10 times smaller than previous technologies, allowed instrument designers to design new integral field spectrographs (IFSs) that are more than 10 times smaller than existing instrument. Successful prototype fabrication and demonstration have resulted in the funding for the two Machined Image Slicer IFUs (MISI) – high resolution MISI-36 with 36 um slicer mirrors and wide-field MISI-116 with 116 um slicer mirror width to upgrade the Diffraction-Limited Near-IR Spectrograph (DL-NIRSP) for DKIST. MISI-36 has already been commissioned in DKIST, and MISI-116 fabrication is near completion. MISI-36 and MISI-116 will provide the most advanced imaging spectropolarimetric capability for solar physics research for years to come. 

The ultra-precision free form micro optics fabrication technology also inspired the Project PI to develop a new, very compact IFS, called Machined Image slicer Compact Spectrographs (MICSs) that integrate a large number of miniature spectrographs into a very compact volume. MICS is a game-changing instrument design. This new design enables wide-spread deployment of compact, high-performance IFSs in the fields, drones and aircrafts, and health care facilities and industrial settings. The project PI have filed patent application for these new designs on behave of the University of Hawaii, which has provided startup funding to help with the commercialization of this new class of IFS. The successful demonstration of MICS prototype has also helped the PI to secure a new funding from the Air Force Office of Scientific Research (AFOSR) for Flare Sentinel, an IFS for the observation of the hydrogen Balmer series spectral lines during solar flares at the Mees Solar Observatory. Flare Sentinel is currently under construction, and when operational, will provide the first ever complete observation of the solar atmosphere’s responses to the magnetic reconnections that power solar flares to provide the observations needed for the understanding of the physics of solar flares, and the development of the forecasting capability of space weather.
